title: 108_s2972
content: The College Savings Act of 2004 increases the maximum annual contribution for Coverdell Education Savings Accounts from $2,000 to $5,000. This amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2004. The College Savings Act of 2004 increases the maximum annual contribution for Coverdell Education Savings Accounts to $5,000 for taxable years starting after December 31, 2004. Additionally, a new section, SEC. 224, is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, allowing for Education Savings Accounts. The College Savings Act of 2004 raises the annual contribution limit for Coverdell Education Savings Accounts to $5,000. Section 224 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces Education Savings Accounts, allowing deductions for contributions made to such accounts by individuals for qualified education expenses. After the beneficiary turns 18, contributions exceeding $5,000 in a taxable year are not allowed unless they are rollover contributions. The trustee must be a bank or demonstrate compliance with IRS requirements. Trust assets cannot be invested. The trust assets cannot be invested in life insurance contracts and must not be commingled with other property. Any balance for the designated beneficiary at age 30 must be distributed within 30 days. Age limitations apply for distributions. The rules for designated beneficiaries with special needs exempt certain provisions. Qualified education expenses are defined as per section 530(b)(2). Various rules from different sections apply for this purpose. The maximum contribution to an account under this section is reduced based on the contributor's adjusted gross income. The reduction is calculated by comparing the contributor's modified adjusted gross income to specified thresholds.
